Mind blowing illusion created by Koukichi Sugihara from the Meiji Institute for Advanced Study of Mathematical Sciences, Japan. Official description/explantion was as follows:

"In this video, wooden balls roll up the slopes just as if they are pulled by a magnet. The behavior of the balls seems impossible, because it is against the gravity. The video is not a computer graphic, but a real scene. What is actually happening is that the orientations of the slopes are perceived oppositely, and hence the descending motion is misinterpreted as ascending motion. This illusion is remarkable in that it is generated by a three-dimensional solid object and physical motion, instead of a two-dimensional picture."

There is a page dedicated to optical illusions over at the main website. See following link.

www.all-about-psychology.com/optical-illusions.html

#OpticalIllusions #psychology Impossible Motion Winner of the Best Visual Illusion of the Year Contest 2010.

Lead by Jason Tangen, a Senior Lecturer in cognition and Matthew Thompson a cognitive scientist, from the The University of Queensland this excellent free to all online course will explore why people believe weird things, how we form and change our opinions, why our expectations skew our judgments, and how we can make better decisions. 

During the course you will discuss and debate topics such as medical diagnosis, paranormal phenomena, placebos, miracles, and more. You will learn how to evaluate claims, make sense of evidence, and understand why we so often make irrational choices; and in doing so, you will begin to rely on slow, effortful, deliberative, analytic, and logical thinking rather than fast, automatic, instinctive, emotional, and stereotypical thinking.

For full details and/or to register for the course see following link.

www.edx.org/course/uqx/uqx-think101x-science-everyday-thinking-1185

If you are lucky enough to be visting the Edinburgh festival this year make sure you book to see Richard Wiseman's Psychobabble talk at the Assembly Rooms on Sunday 4th August. See following link for full details. 

https://www.edfringe.com/whats-on/spoken-word/richard-wiseman-psychobabble
   
Here's the official description:

Best-selling author, psychologist and magician Richard Wiseman rummages around in your mind. Discover how to tell lies, read thoughts and transform a tea towel into a chicken. Several laughs. No Powerpoint. ***** 'you won’t want to miss Psychobabble' (FringeGuru.com). Richard holds Britain’s only Professorship in the Public Understanding of Psychology and researches an eclectic range of topics including luck, self help, illusion and persuasion. Over 2 million people have taken part in his mass participation experiments and he's acted as creative consultant to Derren Brown, The MythBusters, The Mentalist, Heston Blumenthal, Nick Cave and Jeremy Deller.

Why are innocent people wrongfully convicted in certain cases yet acquitted in others? Research is starting to uncover what happens. A new study led Dr. Jon Gould, "Predicting Erroneous Convictions: A Social Science Approach to Miscarriages of Justice" compared cases where innocent defendants were wrongfully convicted to "near misses" – cases in which an innocent defendant was acquitted or had charges dismissed before trial. 

See following link to read/download a PDF of the full study (434 pages).

As promised, more information relating to my last post "The Univited Wedding Guests." 

First of all the picture isn't fake. As is often the case with strange things like this, many people believe that the twelve creepy figures on the balacony represent something paranormal e.g., ghosts, evil spirits, messengers of the apocalypse etc. 

The truth, however, is much more rational. The figures are simply part of an art exhibition by Dawn Dedeaux - ironically entitled, ‘The Goddess Fortuna and Her Dunces in an Effort to Make Sense of It All’ - see following link for full details. 

http://hyperallergic.com/41565/dawn-dedeaux-prospect-2/

THE PSYCHOLOGY OF YOUR FUTURE SELF

Great TED Talk by Harvard psychologist Dan Gilbert. The psychology of your future self "Human beings are works in progress that mistakenly think they're finished." Dan Gilbert shares recent research on a phenomenon he calls the "end of history illusion," where we somehow imagine that the person we are right now is the person we'll be for the rest of time. Hint: that's not the case.

UNSTOPPABLE LEARNING via TED Radio Hour

Why do we put so much effort in making kids think and act like us? TED speakers explore the different ways babies and children learn — from the womb, to the playground, to the web. Unstoppable Learning

THE BIRTH OF A WORD

www.ted.com/talks/deb_roy_the_birth_of_a_word

Cognitive scientist and MIT researcher Deb Roy wanted to understand how his infant son learned language — so he wired up his house with videocameras to catch every moment and parsed 90,000 hours of home video to watch "gaaaa" slowly turn into "water." Astonishing, data-rich research with deep implications for how we learn. Fascinating TED talk. Timeline Photos

The famous NASA "Face on Mars" image taken in 1976 by the Viking 1 orbiter is one of best known examples of Pareidolia i.e., the human tendency to perceive an ambiguous and random stimulus as significant. Satellite photos from a later NASA mission in 2001 shattered the illusion of the original image.

Psychology of Music: What Does it For You?

In preparing for an interview I'm conducting with Yale Fox, I learned from an article he'd written entitled - Why We Experience Goosebumps During A Piece Of Music We Love? -  that the pleasant feeling of chills running up your spine are called "Frissons."

This got me thinking about music that gives me Frissons. The tune that does it for me everytime is Bizzare Love Triangle by New Order (http://youtu.be/W2Ii0K77K1k). 

The eighties was my decade and this anthem transports me straight back there everytime, in fact I've got Frissons right now just thinking about it. 

So What Does it For You? What's your Frisson number one? Post your answer here. I'm sure Yale will be very interested in the results.

In honor of today being John B Watson's birthday the kindle version of Conditioned Emotional Reactions (The Case of Little Albert) is available for free until 11:59 PM Pacific Standard Time. (January 9th)

www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00BOVL3TQ (UK)

Conditioned Emotional Reactions by John B. Watson and Rosalie Rayner is one of the most influential, infamous and iconic research articles ever published in the history of psychology. Commonly referred to as "The Case of Little Albert" this psychology classic attempted to show how fear could be induced in an infant through classical conditioning. 

Bonus Material:

One of the most dramatic aspects of Watson and Rayner's original study was that they had planned to test a number of methods by which they could remove Little Albert's conditioned fear responses. However, as Watson noted "Unfortunately Albert was taken from the hospital the day the above tests were made. Hence the opportunity of building up an experimental technique by means of which we could remove the conditioned emotional responses was denied us."

This unforeseen turn of events was something that obviously stayed with Watson, as under his guidance some three years later, Mary Cover Jones conducted a follow-up study - A Laboratory Study of Fear: The Case of Peter - which illustrated how fear may be removed under laboratory conditions. This additional and highly relevant article is also presented in full.  

If you live outside the USA/UK, just go the Amazon website in your country and type the book title into the search box.

No kindle? No problem. Just download Amazon's free Kindle reading app. See following link for details.

www.amazon.com/dp/B00BSY6WGI (USA)

Originally published in 1946 it was in this landmark publication where Carl Rogers outlined the origins of client-centered therapy, the process of client-centered therapy, the discovery and capacity of the client and the client-centered nature of the therapeutic relationship.

Bonus Content:

Significant Aspects of Client-Centered Therapy builds upon some of Carl Rogers' previously published work. Among the most notable of these earlier articles were The Processes of Therapy and The Development of Insight in A Counseling Relationship; both of which are also presented in full.

A trained micro expressions reader with an extensive background in anatomy and physiology, author Craig-James Baxter has been sharing his knowledge and passion for body language for over 8 years. He has interviewed the world's leading body language experts (Desmond Morris, Paul Ekman, Joe Navarro, David Matsumoto, Carol Kinsey Goman, J.J. Newberry); written for numerous magazines and newspapers and has over 1,000,000 views on YouTube to his name.

In Behind The Mask: What Michael Jackson's Body Language Told The World - Craig-James Baxter's analysis of five infamous video interviews offers a fresh and compelling insight into the world of one of the most popular musicians the world has ever known. 

The interviews covered in the book are: 

1993 Oprah Winfrey Interview. 
1993 Statement from Neverland Ranch. 
1996 Police interview. 
2003 Martin Bashir: Living with Michael Jackson.
2003 Take Two: The Footage You Were Never Meant to See (Martin Bashir Rebuttal Video).

"Transmission of Aggression Through Imitation of Aggressive Models." More commonly known as "The Bobo Doll Experiment," was the first study to explore the impact of televised violence on children. This groundbreaking study by Albert Bandura is one of the most famous psychology studies of all time.

Craig is a trained micro expressions reader with an extensive background in anatomy and physiology who has interviewed the world's leading body language experts (Paul Ekman, David Matsumoto, Carol Kinsey Goman, J.J. Newberry etc.)

Craig's book has received a host of excellent independent reviews. For instance, former FBI spy-catcher Joe Navarro, - recognized as one of the world’s foremost authorities on reading non-verbal communications - wrote:

"Treat yourself to Behind The Mask: What Michael Jackson's Body Language Told The World by Craig Baxter. Whether you are a Michael Jackson fan or a student of nonverbal communications, you will enjoy reading this well researched and documented book."

Following on from my last post, a very warm welcome to http://www.all-about-body-language.com/. I had originally planned just to have a body language section on my psychology website but such is the scope and range of this fascinating topic it soon became clear that it needed a dedicated website to do justice to all the things we intend to cover. I say we because I am extremely fortunate to be developing the website in collaboration with Craig-James Baxter.

Craig is a master trainer in reading advanced micro expressions and is one of the most viewed body language decoders in YouTube’s history, having complied nearly 100 body language analysis videos featuring celebrities, politicians, musicians and high profile criminology cases.

If you're interested in learning more about body language the site already has plenty of information and resources available: Including:

Body language analysis videos
Body language guides
Body language tips
Body language Q & A
Body language articles

And that's just the beginning, we've got some amazing things lined-up, such as exclusive interviews with some of the leading body language experts in the world.

I really hope you enjoy exploring our new website.

Please help us get the word out by liking and sharing this post.

As always, many thanks for your support.

David

In response to the last post, the notion that we only use about 10% of our potential brain power is one of the most pervasive myths among the general public. As award-winning broadcaster, writer and psychology lecturer. Claudia Hammond points out: 

"The myth that we only use 10% of the brain is one which just won't go away. We love the idea that we have this untapped 90% of potential and that if only we could activate a bit of this we could be cleverer, faster and better. I'd like that too, but sadly it just isn't true."

And it's not just members of the public who believe this myth. Surveys have shown that around a third of university psychology students believe the 10 percent myth.

Whether you answered true or false is of far less importance than understanding why we need to tackle brain myths head on, which is something Christian Jarrett, Ph.D addresses in an article for psychology today, which I encourage you to read via the following link.

www.psychologytoday.com/blog/brain-myths/201205/why-its-important-tackle-brain-myths-head

Hi,

My name is David Webb and I'm owner, writer and host of All-About-Psychology.Com - I launched the site in March 2008 and it is now firmly established as a leading educational website and information resource attracting thousands of visitors a day.

Learn more about me here --> https://plus.google.com/u/0/+DavidWebb/about/p/pub

A passionate promoter of psychology through social media, over 850,000 people like the All About Psychology facebook page (this page) and I'm featured on the British Psychological Society list of the 100 most followed psychologists and neuroscientists on Twitter. http://twitter.com/psych101

I'm shortly going to be offering a couple of virtual internships. Nothing too formal, the successful student(s) will be involved with the psychology facebook page - moderating/commenting etc and I'd like to do more with the free classic article initiative (http://bit.ly/FreePsychClassics) so there might be opportunities to help out there as well.

This is very much a part-time, help out as and when you can position, and although it would be unpaid, it will hopefully prove to be an enjoyable experience worthy of inclusion on a resume.

If this sounds like something you might be interested in and you're currently studying psychology just let me know and I'll get back to you as soon as possible. You can either PM me via this page or e-mail me --> david@all-about-psychology.com

Cheers,

David Timeline Photos

WITNESS INVESTIGATION: FREE ONLINE COURSE

www.futurelearn.com/courses/forensic-psychology

ABOUT THE COURSE:

Despite advances in forensic science, eyewitness testimony remains a critical component of criminal investigations. Psychological research has revealed the dangers of relying on evidence gained from an eyewitness and also how careful the police need to be when questioning witnesses.

Using videos of real witnesses and from cameras that go behind the scenes of a police investigation, this course explores the psychology of eyewitness testimony. You will get the chance to test your own cognitive skills and to see whether your powers of investigation are as good as a crack squad of police officers, as you try to solve a crime using nothing but evidence from eyewitnesses.

The course started on 9th June but learners can enrol at any time. Timeline Photos

An outstanding free resource by Dr Paul Howard-Jones, a leading expert on the role of neuroscience in educational practice. The aim of this fascinating publication is to highlight what neuroscience can tell us about the implications of using interactive technologies on young people’s brains, behaviors and attitudes. Lecture 2: The Distributed Cerebral Networks of Mind.

Lecture 3: The Brain Divided: Discovering The "Interpreter."

Lecture 4: The Meaning of Being Free.

Lecture 5: The Social Brain.

Lecture 6: We Are The Law.

Practical tips based on published psychology research.

Improve your memory by resting:

Research published in Psychological Science by Michaela Dewar et al found that a brief (10 minute) wakeful rest following new verbal learning enhances memory for at least 7 days.

So here's a top tip in the week leading up to your exams - after reading each piece of material you need to learn rest quietly with your eyes closed for 10 minutes in a darkened room - because as the authors note:

"In this age of information overload, there are few opportunities to sit back and rest. However, as demonstrated by our findings, postlearning resting can be highly beneficial if one wishes to retain new information over the long term."

You can read the study's abstract via the following link.

http://pss.sagepub.com/content/23/9/955 Timeline Photos

The Making of Individual Differences is just one of the many course units you can access for free via LearningSpace. LearningSpace is an outstanding resource from the Open University that provides free and open educational resources for learners and educators around the world.

The Making of Individual Differences examines the issue of nature and nurture and how genes and the environment interact in the development of the nervous system to make each of us unique. It is not exclusively about biological psychology, however, the module contains some very insightful related material. For instance, make sure you access the sections on the nervous system and genes and their influence on behaviour.

You can access The Making of Individual Differences course unit via the following link.

http://labspace.open.ac.uk/course/view.php?id=3594

I'm sure many of you will have seen or heard about Liverpool soccer player Luis Suárez biting Chelsea defender Branislav Ivanovic. Not since the infamous Holyfield–Tyson biting incident has interest in the psychology of biting been such a hot topic.

The fact is, however, there isn't really much research out there on biting behavior, particularly biting behavior in adults.

Back in 2002 I co-wrote a paper which tentatively suggests reasons for biting behaviours which you might find interesting and can be accessed via the following link (about half way down the page).

The Wisdom of Crowds (Vox Populi) By Francis Galton - Free Full-Text.

See link below to find out how the statistical analysis of an ox weight guessing contest at a farmers' fair demonstrated that the many are smarter than the few.

This particular addition to the psychology journal articles collection was inspired by the exploits of the internationally acclaimed psychological illusionist Derren Brown, who "predicted" the outcome of Britain's National Lottery. Brown put forward "The Wisdom of Crowds" as a possible explantion of how he was able to achieve this apparently incredible feat.

In courtrooms, eyewitness testimony is considered extremely powerful. But should it be? Scott Fraser explains why, even when witnesses feel sure they are telling a true story, or making the right identification, their minds could be playing tricks on them - filling in blanks in traumatic memories with erroneous information.

Fraser is a forensic psychologist who thinks deeply about the fallibility of human memory and encourages a more scientific approach to trial evidence.

Practical tips based on published psychology research.

Improve your memory by resting:

Research published in Psychological Science by Michaela Dewar et al found that a brief (10 minute) wakeful rest following new verbal learning enhances memory for at least 7 days.

So here's a top tip in the week leading up to your exams - after reading each piece of material you need to learn rest quietly with your eyes closed for 10 minutes in a darkened room - because as the authors note:

"In this age of information overload, there are few opportunities to sit back and rest. However, as demonstrated by our findings, postlearning resting can be highly beneficial if one wishes to retain new information over the long term."

You can read the study's abstract via the following link.

http://pss.sagepub.com/content/early/2012/07/23/0956797612441220 Timeline Photos

I've just posted my interview with Dr. Abbie Goldberg over at the All About Psychology website.

Abbie Goldberg, Ph.D., is an Associate Professor in the Department of Psychology at Clark University, and a Senior Research Fellow at the Evan B. Donaldson Adoption Institute.

Dr. Goldberg's interests include how a variety of contexts (e.g., gender, sexual orientation, social class, work-family variables) shape processes of development and mental health; and her research focuses on exploring parenthood, relationship quality, and well-being in diverse families (e.g., adoptive parent families, lesbian/gay parent families) in an effort to increase our understanding of family diversity.

How do you remember where you parked your car? How do you know if you're moving in the right direction? Neuroscientist Neil Burgess studies the neural mechanisms that map the space around us, and how they link to memory and imagination.

Yale Fox researches social nightclub behaviour with a particular emphasis on music and how it affects people at an implicit level. With a background in biology, psychology, and sociology, Fox investigates such topics as how music can affect bar sales and people's ability to multitask, how it determines listening patterns, and how the stock market can affect mood, which in turn predicts the characteristics of popular music. 

Fox's research has been published in international publications, documentaries, and textbooks. Additionally, Yale's position in the nightclub industry gives him access to a vast quantity of unique data, which has already led to some remarkable conclusions.

For more information on this fascinating research, check out Yale Fox's blog on the science of nightlife - http://www.darwinvsthemachine.com/

Stalking Victimization In The United States (Free Full-Text Report)

Stalking Victimization in the United States was written by BJS statisticians Katrina Baum, Shannan Catalano, Michael Rand, and Kristina Rose of the National Institute of Justice.

The report presents findings on nonfatal stalking victimization in the U.S., based on the largest data collection of such behavior to date. Topics covered in the report are stalking and harassment prevalence rates by demographic characteristics, offender characteristics, victim-offender relationship, duration of stalking, cyberstalking, protection measures, and emotional impact. The report also includes data on whether victim sought help from others, involvement of a weapon, injuries, other crimes perpetrated by the stalker, and response by the criminal justice system.

You can read the report in full via the following link.

http://bjs.ojp.usdoj.gov/content/pub/pdf/svus.pdf Timeline Photos

In 1905 legendary psychologist William James published a tribute to the memory of his very good friend and eminent philosopher Thomas Davidson. Within his tribute James referred to a letter Davidson had written in which he summed up the results of his own experience of life by way of a series of maxims. This was one of those pearls of wisdom. Timeline Photos

Written by a lecturer in psychology and designed to let you dive straight into this fascinating topic, Criminal Profiling: An Introductory Guide is based on a series of classes from an undergraduate program in forensic psychology.

The guide provides clear and concise information on central issues such as the origins of criminal profiling, FBI profiling methodology and limitations; and whether becoming a profiler is a realistic career path.

He's done it again! Thanks to Luis Suárez biting behavior is big news. There is actually very little research on the psychology of biting behavior in adults, although back in 2002 I had a paper published in the Journal of Forensic Science which explored the forensic implications of biting behaviour within the context on a criminal investigation; given that bitemarks are often found on the victims of violent and sexual crime.

If you you would like to read this paper, go here --> www.all-about-psychology.com/psychology-website.html and scroll down to where it says Click Here To Read The Biting Behavior Article.

The Trauma & Mental Health Report (http://trauma.blog.yorku.ca/) is a weekly online mental-health magazine published out of York University in Toronto.  Its purpose is to share research-based knowledge with members of the community, on the topic of interpersonal trauma. 

The Trauma & Mental Health Report  cover issues like the causes and consequences of trauma; treatment, prevention, and implications of trauma for society at large. The contributing writers who are all students in the Trauma & Attachment Lab at York University draw on primary sources including interviews with survivors, therapists, and others who work in the field of interpersonal trauma. 

The aim of The Trauma & Mental Health Report is to disseminate knowledge by including research published in reputable scientific journals, in a manner that can be readily understood by readers.

Many thanks to Shira Yufe for letting me know about this excellent resource.

#Trauma #MentalHealth #YorkUniversityToronto Timeline Photos

I've just published The Essential Guide To Criminal Profiling on the kindle. The guide is based on a series of classes I gave as part of an undergraduate program in forensic psychology.

The guide explores a range of topics including, the origins of criminal profiling, FBI profiling, methodology and effectiveness and whether becoming a profiler is a realistic career choice.

As with my other kindle publications, the proceeds from any sales will go towards the running and hosting costs associated with the four websites built around my teaching and research interests.

I'm listening to the compelling verdict statement in the Oscar Pistorius trial. Judge Thokozile Masipa noted 'probability some witnesses failed to separate what they knew personally from what they gathered in media.' This very same issue raised during a murder trial in 1896 was a defining moment in the history of forensic psychology

A comprehensive guide to the world of forensic psychology.

Highlights on the website include:

A detailed and clear account of what forensic psychology actually is. Important because of the way the subject has been distorted, sensationalised and inaccurately presented in books, films and on TV. See following link.

http://www.all-about-forensic-psychology.com/what-is-forensic-psychology.html

A series of information pages on criminal profiling. A fascinating subject to learn about in iteslf but also important to know of its place within forensic psychology; for example is criminal profiling a realistic career goal? See following link.

http://www.all-about-forensic-psychology.com/fbi-profiler.html

The Forensic Psychology Degree Directory. A great resource for anybody thinking about studying forensic psychology. See following link.

http://www.all-about-forensic-psychology.com/forensic-psychology-degree.html

Free full-text articles. A wonderful collection of publications including a special "Inside the Criminal Mind" collection showcasing all the major articles written by members of the Behavioral Science Units, National Center for the Analysis of Violent Crime, at the FBI Academy. See following link.

http://www.all-about-forensic-psychology.com/forensic-psychology-ebook.html

I really hope that you find all the information and resources on the All About Forensic Psychology website useful and engaging.

David Webb BSc (hons), MSc Forensic Psychology

Dr Jarrett has a PhD in cognitive neuroscience and is a chartered psychologist and associate fellow of the British Psychological Society (BPS). He has edited and written the BPS Research Digest since its inception in 2003 and created the associated BPS Research Digest blog in 2005. In producing this award-winning blog Dr. Jarrett reviews hundreds of peer-reviewed journals in order to report on the latest findings within psychological science.

In 2005 the FBI’s National Center for the Analysis of Violent Crime, Behavioral Analysis Unit hosted a 5 day symposium on serial murder. Their goal was to bring together experts on serial murder in order to identify commonalities of knowledge.

One of the issues addressed during this unique symposium was the fact that the rarity of serial murder combined with inaccurate, anecdotal and fictional portrayals of serial killers has resulted in a number of common misconceptions arising. As a result of their deliberations, the expert panel identified 7 main serial killer myths, the details of which can be accessed via the following link.

http://www.all-about-forensic-psychology.com/serial-killers.html Timeline Photos

Free full-text copy of one of the most frequently Cited Journal Articles in Introductory Psychology Textbooks. Building on psychological research that maintained that short-term memory is restricted to just a few bits of information, this classic paper by George A Miller showed among other things how chunking could be employed to increase the restricted capacity of short-term memory. The Magical Number Seven, Plus or Minus Two: Some Limits on Our Capacity for Processing Information" is among the most frequently cited journal articles in introductory psychology textbooks. 

Building on psychological research that maintained that short-term memory is restricted to just a few bits of information, this famous paper by George A Miller showed among other things how chunking could be employed to increase the restricted capacity of short-term memory.

This memoir is a recollection of powerful recovery based information from Steve Colori's experiences with facing and overcoming schizoaffective disorder. Steve has published seven articles with Oxford Medical Journals on Schizoaffective disorder and five of these are within this text. 

To have schizoaffective disorder a patient has to be diagnosed with all the symptoms of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder simultaneously. Steve's memoir is well-written, insightful, and fascinating and is useful for patients, family members, and medical staff. Timeline Photos

Originally presented by Anne Anastasi as an address of the President of the American Psychological Association in 1957 this child psychology and nature nurture debate classic argues that the question "How?" offers a much more constructive approach to the heredity-environment problem; as opposed to the question "Which one?" or "How much?"

Originally published in 1946 Significant Aspects of Client-Centered Therapy is essential reading for anybody interested in psychotherapy and counseling. In this landmark publication Carl Rogers outlines the origins of client-centered therapy, the process of client-centered therapy, the discovery and capacity of the client and the client-centered nature of the therapeutic relationship.

Bonus Content:

Significant Aspects of Client-Centered Therapy builds upon some of Carl Rogers' previously published work. Among the most notable of these earlier articles were The Processes of Therapy and The Development of Insight in A Counseling Relationship; both of which are also presented in full. Timeline Photos

Despite his premature death at the age of just 37, Lev Vygotsky is widely considered as one of the leading developmental psychologists of the 20th century. In addition to his seminal contribution to the relationship between language and thought, Lev Vygotsky also put forward ideas regarding the psychology of play, in particular the process of self-regulation through creative play.

This classic article which was originally given in the form of a speech provides several key insights into Lev Vygotsky's theories of play. Timeline Photos

Described by eminent psychologist Richard Gregory as "perhaps the most famous experiment in the whole of experimental psychology," George Malcolm Stratton spent several days continuously wearing specially adapted lenses which inverted his visual image up and down and left and right. Stratton's novel and pioneering studies served as a catalyst for research into binocular vision and depth perception which continues to this day. 

Between November 1896 and September 1897 Stratton published his experimental aims and experiences in the Psychological Review, the full details of which are contained herein. Timeline Photos
